articles.title: Qld school probed over gender contracts
articles.text:
Qld school probed over gender contracts Queensland's education minister has urged a Brisbane Penecostal Christian school to revoke student gender and sexuality contracts amid two probes into the controversial pacts.

Citipointe Christian College in Carindale is facing a possible review of its state funding and anti-discrimination action over the contracts sent to parents last week ahead of the start of the school year next Monday.

The pacts said "the college will only enrol the student on the b ...

articles.title: 'Heartbroken' teacher quits over LGBT stance
articles.text:
'Heartbroken' teacher quits over LGBT stance A teacher at Citipointe Christian College has quit her job over the school's recent enrolment contract controversy.

The Carindale school in Queensland sent out an updated contract for parents to sign ahead of students returning to school.

The contract states the school can terminate a child's enrolment if they do not identify with their birth gender.

The contract has sparked major outrage, with more than 32,400 people signing a Change.org petition  ...

articles.title: Moderate Liberals to push for protections for gay students
articles.text:
Moderate Liberals to push for protections for gay students The Spectator's Caroline Di Russo says she doesn't think protections for gay students under the proposed religious discrimination bill is a hill for "moderate libs to die on".

The Age has reported federal moderate Liberal MPs will renew a push for protections for LGBTQIA+ students when Parliament returns next week.

"The federal government really need a win, this is something that has been on the books for a long time," Ms Di Russo said ...

articles.title: 'Religion used as a mask': College could lose funding over controversial contract
articles.text:
'Religion used as a mask': College could lose funding over controversial contract A Christian college that provoked public uproar for its controversial contract forcing children to accept gender roles could lose funding and be subject to anti-discrimination action within days.

But Queensland's Attorney-General, Shannon Fentiman, has warned a Morrison government proposal could still give Brisbane's Citipointe Christian College, and other schools, the power to discriminate against students based  ...

articles.title: Citipointe College principal breaks his silence
articles.text:
Citipointe College principal breaks his silence The principal of a school which has outraged gay and transgender communities across Australia has spoken for the first time defending the policies of the Christian college in Brisbane.

Sky News has uncovered a recorded address from the headmaster to parents, seeking to justify the policies of the Citipointe College in the city's east.

The video was recorded as the Queensland government referred the school to the Human Rights Commission for discri ...

articles.text:

Citipointe Christian College in Carindale sent out an updated enrolment contract for parents to sign ahead of students returning to school.

The contract states the school can terminate a child's enrolment if they do not identify with their bir ...

articles.text:
'Beyond shameful': Brisbane school faces growing backlash over 'unacceptable' enrolment contract A Brisbane Christian college's enrolment contract that demands families denounce homosexuality and subscribe to traditional gender roles is "unacceptable", and a review is under way into whether the school is in breach of its legislative obligations, Queensland's Education Minister says.

articles.title: Citipointe principal speaks out, extends signing date for contract
articles.text:
Citipointe principal speaks out, extends signing date for contract Citipointe Christian College's principal has pushed back on the Queensland government over its referral to have the school reviewed, and has instead extended the signing date for the controversial contract that sparked an uproar.

Principal Brian Mulheran issued a six-minute-long video to parents on Tuesday night in a bid to reassure families that the school "does not judge students on the basis of sexuality or gender identity".

articles.title: Lord mayor to raise 'concerns' with Christian college over contracts
articles.text:
Lord mayor to raise 'concerns' with Christian college over contracts Brisbane's lord mayor says he will raise concerns with the principal of his former school, who issued a contract insisting students denounce homosexuality and asked them to agree to specific gender roles.

Citipointe Christian College has already been warned by the Queensland Human Rights Commission that forcing existing students to comply with the controversial contract would likely amount to unlawful discrimination.

The cont ...

articles.title: School blasted for 'inhumane' contract
articles.text:
School blasted for 'inhumane' contract Citipointe Christian College in Carindale sent out an updated enrolment contract for parents to sign little over a week ahead of students retuning to school.

The contract states the school can terminate a child's enrolment if they do not identify with their birth gender.

It notes the bible ties gender identity to biological sex and does not make a distinction between gender and biological sex.

articles.title: Brisbane's Citipointe Christian College principal Brian Mulheran steps down
articles.text:
Brisbane's Citipointe Christian College principal Brian Mulheran steps down The principal of Brisbane's Citipointe Christian College that has been embroiled in a student enrolment row has announced he will stand aside to take extended leave.

Citipointe Christian College came under fire this week over its controversial sexuality and gender identity clauses in its contract with families.

That contract -- which described homosexuality as a sin and compared it to bestiality and paedophilia -- was  ...

articles.title: Principal steps down over anti-gay contract
articles.text:
Principal steps down over anti-gay contract The principal of a Brisbane Christian school will "stand aside" after asking parents to sign a controversial anti-gay and anti-trans enrolment contract.

Citipointe Christian College withdrew its enrolment contract on Thursday which would have allowed the school to expel students based on their gender identity.

The contract also branded homosexuality "sinful, offensive and destructive" and lumped it into the same category as paedophilia and incest.

N ...

articles.title: Citipointe Christian College withdraws controversial gender contract
articles.text:
Citipointe Christian College withdraws controversial gender contract Citipointe Christian College in Queensland has revoked a controversial enrolment contract which would have forced students to identify with their birth gender.

The college was due to be reviewed on Thursday by Queensland's Non-State School Accreditation Board after complaints were made to the education minister about the contract.

In a video message released by the principal on Tuesday night, he refused to apologise for it, s ...

articles.title: Conservatives have overplayed their hand on religious freedom bill
articles.text:
Conservatives have overplayed their hand on religious freedom bill The long-running debate over the Coalition's religious freedom bill has been turned upside down in the last week after the federal government made a significant concession to the LGBTQI community.

Prime Minister Scott Morrison was hoping to use the bill, expected to come to a vote in Parliament in the next two weeks, in his pitch to religious voters at the next election and as a wedge issue against Labor.

The documents said "the college will only enrol the student on the basis of the gender that corresponds to their biological sex" and said homosexuality is "sinful" ...

articles.text:

articles.text:

articles.text:
Morrison to push plan to protect gay students Scott Morrison will stare down conservative Coalition MPs and seek to change the Sex Discrimination Act alongside landmark religious freedom laws, pledging action before the federal election.

Despite opposition within his own partyroom to ending legal protections for faith-based schools to expel gay and lesbian students, the Prime Minister said he intended to take up the compromise move pushed by moderate Liberal MPs.

articles.text:
Brisbane Christian school withdraws sexuality contract after backlash A Brisbane religious school has withdrawn a controversial enrolment contract sent to parents last week, after a backlash from parents and the broader community.

The contract demanded families denounce homosexuality and that students identify by birth gender, or risk being excluded from the school.

Citipointe Christian College's contract describes homosexuality as a sin and compares it to bestiality and paedophilia.

articles.text:

articles.title: Cynical vote grabbing or genuine concern: the Religious Discrimination Bill unpacked
articles.text:
Cynical vote grabbing or genuine concern: the Religious Discrimination Bill unpacked Following a marathon session of Parliament overnight, the federal government's contentious Religious Discrimination Bill has passed through the House of Representatives.

The government's proposal was that religious schools would be banned from expelling students based on their sexual orientation, but those same rights were not extended to transgender students.

In a blow to the government, an amendment to prote ...

articles.title: Every child deserves protection of the law
articles.text:
Every child deserves protection of the law Compromise and politics go hand in hand. Every law that is passed in Parliament has a backstory of give and take. The Religious Discrimination Bill being debated this week in Canberra has a longer and more contentious backstory than most.

Born out of the same-sex plebiscite of 2017, it has been redrafted several times under the watchful eyes of two attorneys-general and Prime Minister Scott Morrison in an attempt to find a middle ground that will placa ...

articles.title: The lesson from overseas is that the battle for trans rights isn't going away
articles.text:
The lesson from overseas is that the battle for trans rights isn't going away While campaigning for the Democratic Party's presidential nomination in early 2020, Joe Biden declared that transgender equality was the "civil rights issue of our time".

"There is no room for compromise when it comes to basic human rights," the future president wrote on Twitter - a statement that underlined the increasingly prominent role transgender rights plays in American politics today.

The US Supreme Court's 20 ...

articles.title: 'Essence of the bill is forgotten': Religious leaders urge government to focus
articles.text:
'Essence of the bill is forgotten': Religious leaders urge government to focus Minority religious leaders have urged the federal government to focus on the core purpose of its religious discrimination bill after parliamentary debate became consumed by an amendment about transgender students' rights and was indefinitely delayed on Thursday.

Chair of the western Sydney-based Australian Sikh Association, Ravi Singh, said he feared the bill had lost its appeal with the public because of this week's ...

articles.text:

articles.title: Labor pushes for changes to Morrison's religious freedom plan
articles.text:
Labor pushes for changes to Morrison's religious freedom plan Labor will push for changes to Scott Morrison's religious freedom laws, seeking to give legal protection to both students and teachers and to scuttle provisions designed to allow offensive speech in public settings.

Opposition MPs opted against a plan to oppose the legislation on Wednesday after lengthy meetings of shadow cabinet and the Labor caucus. Instead, Labor will seek to prohibit discrimination in faith-based aged care and ba ...

articles.title: Government consulting religious groups on next steps after defeat on discrimination bill
articles.text:
Government consulting religious groups on next steps after defeat on discrimination bill The government says it will return to religious groups to consult on the future of its contentious religious discrimination bill, following a dramatic defeat when it was put to a vote overnight.

In the early hours of this morning, five Liberal MPs joined Labor and the crossbench to vote against the government and extend protections for transgender school staff and students from discrimination.

The religiou ...

articles.title: The government lost a dramatic showdown on religious discrimination laws overnight. What happens next?
articles.text:
The government lost a dramatic showdown on religious discrimination laws overnight. What happens next? The government suffered a major defeat on the floor of the House of Representatives overnight as MPs debated its contentious religious discrimination laws in a sitting which lasted until dawn was breaking over Canberra.

In dramatic scenes, several of the government's own MPs voted with the opposition to have the government's own bill amended.

It's not unusual for Liberal politicians to cross  ...

articles.text:
Australia news LIVE: Religious discrimination bill debate dominates Parliament; total COVID-19 cases continue to grow across the nation Federal Labor frontbencher Stephen Jones has revealed the suicide of his gay nephew and fears for his own high-heel wearing son's safety in a powerful intervention during debate on the proposed Religious Discrimination Bill.

The revelations made by the opposition frontbencher in Parliament last night put pressure on Labor to formally oppose the government's pro ...

articles.title: The five MPs who crossed the floor
articles.text:
The five MPs who crossed the floor After a tense all-night affair, the federal government's contentious Religious Discrimination Bill passed the House of Representatives.

Five Liberal MPs rebelled by crossing the floor to vote with Labor in support of a crossbench amendment to bolster protections for gay teachers and ensure transgender students were included.

The amendments pertain to 38(3) of the Sex Discrimination Act that allows religious schools to discriminate against students on the basi ...

articles.text:

articles.title: The failure of Gonski is a failure for all students
articles.text:
The failure of Gonski is a failure for all students There is not much mixing of the rich and poor in today's lopsided system; religious schools overwhelmingly cater for those who can pay fees, in the process creating a socioeconomic hierarchy. This isn't pluralism, it is discrimination and separation based largely on circumstances of birth. The MySchool website shows how this plays out in every community.

articles.text:

articles.title: Gay men lured to park and beaten: cops
articles.text:
Gay men lured to park and beaten: cops Three gay men have been assaulted at a Melbourne park after allegedly been catfished by a group of teenage boys on a dating app.

The trio were allegedly lured to a reserve on Harlequin Ave at Ashwood, in the city's east, across different dates in December and January.

Once at the park, police alleged the men were verbally abused with homophobic comments and assaulted.

A 42-year-old man from Ashwood was allegedly assaulted on December 18, 2021, at about 1 ...

articles.text:

Alleged co-conspirators Hector Robles, aka Oreja, Luis Cruz, aka Mostro, and Carlos Macci, aka Carlito, were charged as members of the fentanyl and heroin conspiracy.

articles.title: Elderly man hospitalised after unprovoked attack
articles.text:
Elderly man hospitalised after unprovoked attack A 76-year-old man has received severe facial injuries after being attacked at a seafood restaurant on Marine Terrace.

The man was sitting in the restaurant's outdoor seating area about 5.10pm on Wednesday when an unknown man approached him.

The offender punched the victim in the face causing him to fall back into a flower bed.

The offender then punched the victim whilst he was on the ground.

articles.title: POLICE HUNT: Search for caravan axe attackers ramps up
articles.text:
POLICE HUNT: Search for caravan axe attackers ramps up Police are still on the hunt for the men who viciously attacked two men while they slept in a Guilderton holiday park, leaving one of them fighting for life.

The victims, aged 49 and 60, were asleep in a Guilderton Caravan Park home when a "number of men" armed with axes forced their way in about 1.45am on Sunday morning.

Police say the attackers, believed to be strangers to the victims, viciously assaulted the pair before fleeing the scen ...

articles.title: Officer A denies inmate's manslaughter
articles.text:
Officer A denies inmate's manslaughter A prison officer has pleaded not guilty to the manslaughter of an Indigenous inmate who was shot dead while trying to escape from a northern NSW hospital.

The accused, referred to as Officer A, was arraigned in the NSW Supreme Court on Friday, when he pleaded not guilty to unlawfully killing Dwayne Johnstone.

Justice Robert Allan Hulme, who was told the case was "difficult and novel", set the trial down for October 10.

It's estimated to run for three wee ...

articles.title: Shooting victim begged police to kill him
articles.text:
Shooting victim begged police to kill him Shooting victim begged police to kill himRobyn WuthAAPTue, 15 February 2022 10:12AM

A man armed with a samurai sword begged officers to kill him before he was shot dead southwest of Brisbane, a Queensland coroner has been told.

Duy Linh Ho, 41, was high on ice when he barricaded himself in the bathroom of his family home at Doolandella in July 2019.

A pre-inquest conference in Brisbane Coroners Court was told Mr Ho was depressed and struggled with opi ...

articles.title: Prison-bashing culprit 'worst candidate' for community-based order: prosecutor
articles.text: Prison-bashing culprit 'worst candidate' for community-based order: prosecutor One of two men found guilty of viciously bashing a fellow jail inmate deserves a significant jail term despite the risk of being institutionalised because he is "perhaps one of the worst candidates for a community-based order," a prosecutor has said. In November, Cedric Roberts, 24, and Brendon Walters, 27, were found guilty of assault occasioning actual bodily harm against a fellow inmate at the Alexander Maconochie  ...

articles.title: Medical expert tells court second shot fired by NT police officer Zachary Rolfe killed Kumanjayi Walker
articles.text:
Medical expert tells court second shot fired by NT police officer Zachary Rolfe killed Kumanjayi Walker A medical expert has told the murder trial of Northern Territory police officer Zachary Rolfe that the second of three gunshots fired during a struggle with Kumanjayi Walker likely caused the 19-year-old's death.

WARNING: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander readers are advised that this article contains an image of a person who has died, used with the permission of their family.

The shots  ...

articles.title: Conviction poses questions for owners of stolen art
articles.text: Conviction poses questions for owners of stolen art A trial was avoided as Mr Evans pleaded guilty to 35 charges of using his position dishonestly to gain advantage. He was sentenced this week to four years and six months in jail with a non-parole period of 20 months. He was also ordered to pay a total of $421,378.20 to the corporation, the estate of Sally Gabori and other artists. The reparations ordered by the court represent the total amount that Mr Evans had sold the works for, suggesting th ...

articles.title: Police hunt group after SAVAGE Perth home invasion
articles.text:
Police hunt group after SAVAGE Perth home invasion Detectives are on the hunt for a group of burglars who stormed a Southern River home on Friday and bashed the occupant.

The terrifying ordeal happened about 11pm, when a group of offenders with their faces covered, forced entry into a home on Brahma Street.

Once inside they assaulted the home's occupant, a man in his 40s.

The offenders stole various items from the home.

The victim was conveyed to Armadale Hospital for treatment to his injuri ...

articles.title: Taxi driver 'punched, bitten' in Northbridge attack
articles.text:
Taxi driver 'punched, bitten' in Northbridge attack A taxi driver was punched and bitten by two passengers who allegedly refused to pay for a trip in Northbridge in the early hours of Saturday.

Police say two passengers, a woman and a man, had refused to pay for the ride before they started attacking the driver, punching and biting him.

As the taxi driver headed towards a police station, police say the front seat passenger grabbed the steering wheel, causing the taxi to hit a parked Mercedes B ...

articles.title: Ex-officers violated George Floyd's rights
articles.text:
Ex-officers violated George Floyd's rights Three former Minneapolis police officers have been found guilty of depriving George Floyd of his rights by failing to give aid to the handcuffed Black man pinned beneath a colleague's knee.

The jury's verdict against Tou Thao, 36; J Alexander Kueng, 28; and Thomas Lane, 38, came in a case that hinged on when an officer has a duty to intervene in another's misconduct. It is a rare instance of police officers being held criminally responsible for a colle ...

articles.title: Former coroner condemns police inaction on paedophilia admission in sworn evidence
articles.text:
Former coroner condemns police inaction on paedophilia admission in sworn evidence Queensland police have never charged a convicted paedophile who admitted under oath at an inquest to having committed sexual offences against a 15-year-old.

The decision has outraged the now-retired coroner who oversaw the court hearings.

John Hutton, who was a coroner between 2008 and 2017, has taken aim at the Queensland police for not pursuing charges over the man's sworn evidence at a 2016 inquest in what Mr ...

articles.title: Former Minneapolis police officers found guilty of depriving George Floyd of his rights before his death
articles.text:
Former Minneapolis police officers found guilty of depriving George Floyd of his rights before his death Three former Minneapolis police officers have been found guilty of depriving George Floyd of his rights by failing to give aid to the handcuffed black man pinned beneath a colleague's knee.

The jury also found that the conduct of officers Tou Thao, Alexander Kueng and Thomas Lane caused Mr Floyd's death, a finding that can affect the severity of their sentence.

The case hinged on questions  ...

articles.title: Confronting footage shown at Constable Zachary Rolfe's murder trial paints a picture of panic in Yuendumu
articles.text:
Confronting footage shown at Constable Zachary Rolfe's murder trial paints a picture of panic in Yuendumu "The footage which is about to be played is disturbing and if that is likely to cause anybody any problems, they should now leave the court."

The warning to the public gallery is given by Justice John Burns before pieces of police body-worn camera vision are played to the murder trial of Constable Zachary Rolfe in the Northern Territory Supreme Court.

WARNING: This article contains body-wo ...

articles.title: Cop car hits dirt bike rider
articles.text:
Cop car hits dirt bike rider Police have crashed with a dirt bike in Sydney's south, with the rider taken to hospital for treatment.

Officers attached to South Sydney Police Area Command were responding to a job when they hit the trail bike near the intersection of Henderson and Mitchell roads, Eveleigh, just after 7.30am on Saturday.

The male rider was taken to Royal Prince Alfred Hospital in a stable condition for treatment.

A crime scene has been established and a critical incident team fr ...

articles.title: Grace Tame breaks silence over awkward photo with PM
articles.text:
Grace Tame breaks silence over awkward photo with PM Grace Tame addresses awkward encounter with PM: 'Many women are sick of being told to smile'Bryce LuffThe West AustralianWed, 2 February 2022 9:58AMEmail Bryce Luff

Grace Tame has broken her silence on the frosty meeting with Prime Minister Scott Morrison, saying "the survival of abuse culture is dependent on submissive smiles and self-defeating surrenders".

The sexual assault survivor was stony faced during snaps with the PM and hardly appe ...

articles.title: Morrison seeks to defend record on women
articles.text:
Morrison seeks to defend record on women Morrison seeks to defend record on womenGeorgie MooreAAPTue, 1 February 2022 1:21PM

Scott Morrison has sought to defend his record on women, insisting federal parliament is a safer place since an alleged rape in a minister's office.

The prime minister pointed to an independent complaints mechanism set up last year after former Liberal staffer Brittany Higgins went public about her alleged 2019 rape at the hands of a colleague.

"That process that we exa ...

articles.title: 'Over being told to smile': Tame speaks on frosty PM meeting
articles.text:
'Over being told to smile': Tame speaks on frosty PM meeting Grace Tame has broken her silence on the frosty meeting with Prime Minister Scott Morrison, saying "the survival of abuse culture is dependent on submissive smiles and self-defeating surrenders".

The sexual assault survivor was stony faced during snaps with the PM and hardly appeared excited at the idea of shaking his hand at a morning tea at The Lodge for Australian of the Year finalists last week.

Taking to Twitter on Wednesday, Ms ...

articles.title: In defence of Miranda Hobbes (and quitting your old life)
articles.text:
In defence of Miranda Hobbes (and quitting your old life) If you're still watching And Just Like That, there's a good chance you're disappointed in Miranda Hobbes.

The woman who came to symbolise justifiable cynicism about dating in the late 90s and early 2000s, had, in the last decade, grown in our minds to become not merely Carrie's North Star, but a fully-fledged protagonist in her own right. A feminist touchstone - one we found more aspirational than a pair of blue satin Manolo Blahniks.

Y ...

articles.title: Staffer mistreatment to be acknowledged
articles.text:
Staffer mistreatment to be acknowledged Staffer mistreatment to be acknowledgedAndrew BrownAAPTue, 8 February 2022 5:48AM

An acknowledgement of the bullying and harassment experienced by parliamentary staff will be delivered when federal parliament resumes for the year on Tuesday.

The statement of acknowledgement will be delivered at the start of parliament by the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the President of the Senate.

Prime Minister Scott Morrison and Opposition Leader Anton ...

articles.title: Lib told not to go to Tame, Higgins speech
articles.text:
Lib told not to go to Tame, Higgins speech Lib told not to go to Tame, Higgins speechDominic GianniniAAPMon, 7 February 2022 11:32AM

One female Liberal backbencher says it's "disgusting" they have been told not to attend the speeches of Grace Tame and Brittany Higgins this week.

Ms Tame and Ms Higgins will front the National Press Club on Wednesday after making their opposition to the prime minister's treatment of women and lack of action on women's issues well known.

A Liberal backbencher to ...

articles.title: Rain Dove went undercover as a man while helping in NSW's bushfire relief
articles.text:
Rain Dove went undercover as a man while helping in NSW's bushfire relief An American model has revealed how they had to go "undercover" while volunteering during NSW's devastating black summer bushfires of 2019/2020 to stay "safe".

Rain Dove, a gender-nonconforming model and activist, chose to present as a cisgendered man throughout the trip, so as to remain safe and provide help without causing any distraction.

In a video uploaded this week detailing the experience, Dove explained how they w ...

articles.title: Seasonal workers in spotlight of inquiry
articles.text:
Seasonal workers in spotlight of inquiry Seasonal workers in spotlight of inquiryMaeve BannisterAAPWed, 2 February 2022 12:32AM

Seasonal workers will share their experiences of the impacts of job insecurity at a hearing on Wednesday.

Last year the Senate inquiry into job security heard from academics, banking staff and rideshare drivers about the demoralising and stressful outcomes of being employed casually.

In a submission to the committee, the Australian Workers' Union calls for amendments ...

articles.title: How to get a pay rise: bold advice for Aussies
articles.text:
How to get a pay rise: bold advice for Aussies Australians wanting to earn more money will be urged to switch jobs by the federal Treasurer, in a bid to keep the country's labour market growing.

In a speech to the Australian Industry Group on Monday, Josh Frydenberg will encourage Australians to take advantage of a "great reshuffle" to score a pay rise and drive unemployment rates down.

Mr Frydenberg will quote Treasury analysis that shows a record 300,000 workers in the December quarter said  ...

articles.title: Treasurer tells Aussies how to get a pay rise
articles.text:
Treasurer tells Aussies how to get a pay rise Australians wanting to earn more money will be urged to switch jobs by the federal Treasurer, in a bid to keep the country's labour market growing.

In a speech to the Australian Industry Group on Monday, Josh Frydenberg will encourage Australians to take advantage of a "great reshuffle" to score a pay rise and drive unemployment rates down.

Mr Frydenberg will quote Treasury analysis that shows a record 300,000 workers in the December quarter said t ...

articles.title: Could Australia learn from Singapore to make housing more affordable?
articles.text:
Could Australia learn from Singapore to make housing more affordable? Singapore is an island city-state with about 300,000 more residents than greater Sydney, but far less than 10 per cent of its land area.

Yet, according to economist Cameron Murray, it has managed to boost home ownership for 25-34-year-olds from 60 to nearly 90 per cent over the past four decades, at a time when the percentage of Australians that age who own a home has plunged from 60 to 45 per cent.

So, how have they done it ...

articles.title: Stay-at-home trend may hurt economy - and your mood
articles.text:
Stay-at-home trend may hurt economy - and your mood The pandemic fuelled a race for space by cooped-up city dwellers. But US evidence suggests the increase in relocations was temporary. The long-term trend is for people to stay put. In 2021, individuals were less than half as likely to move as they were in the 1970s, according to the US census.

Even so, Americans are more footloose than citizens of almost all other countries. An exception is Australia, where nearly half the country moves within ...

articles.title: Australia is out of denial on debt, but has no will to act
articles.text:
Australia is out of denial on debt, but has no will to act Commonwealth budgets and mid-year reviews have been ramping up spending, right up to the last mid-year review in December. As a result, spending in 2023/24 is estimated to be $41 billion higher than when it was first estimated in 2020. This increase has little to do with the pandemic.

The fiscal outlook is further clouded by the approach of a federal election. In recent weeks, the Prime Minister has been out and about sprinkling more fi ...

articles.title: Australian business falling behind global peers on 'productivity frontier'
articles.text:
Australian business falling behind global peers on 'productivity frontier' Australian businesses are failing to invest in cutting-edge technologies to improve their operations as fast as their peers overseas, with research revealing a lack of competitive pressure is hurting local firms and keeping prices higher for consumers.

The federal Treasury analysis shows the gap between Australian businesses and global leaders on the "productivity frontier" has widened since the early part of this centur ...

articles.title: More migrants, more women, more productivity to boost the recovery
articles.text:
More migrants, more women, more productivity to boost the recovery For this reason, the budget needs to address the problems of acute worker shortages and record low business investment while also laying the foundations to secure Australia's economic future through a diverse, strong and innovative industry structure with better jobs and higher wages.

The Business Council's budget submission puts forward a combination of short-term practical measures and long-term initiatives to keep the recover ...

articles.title: An uncompetitive tax system is now holding Australia back
articles.text:
An uncompetitive tax system is now holding Australia back The Henry review told us that over-reliance on personal income tax would create disincentives to workforce participation.

Today, businesses are scrambling to find labour and we are looking for ways to get the participation rate up. In the government's medium-term fiscal projections, personal income tax is the only growing tax base, suggesting we will rely more and more on bracket creep in the years ahead to fund public services unless th ...

articles.title: Childcare centre landlord lifts payout as inflation boosts rents
articles.text:
Childcare centre landlord lifts payout as inflation boosts rents Almost half of the trust's tenants in the heavily subsidised sector were hit with CPI-linked rent increases over the six months to December. A further 40 percent face similar rent escalations in the second half of the year.

Alongside stronger rental growth, the acquisition of six Adelaide childcare centres for $38 million after December 31, and the completion of seven new childcare centres, will drive higher earnings in the second ...

articles.title: Your car as a workspace and other big transportation trends
articles.text:
Your car as a workspace and other big transportation trends "The instant power makes them more fun," Savic tells Machine. "You just twist and go. The range is a slight limitation, but for most motorcycle riding, the range that we have [between 150 kilometres and 200 kilometres] fits the bill. I think the lower amount of maintenance makes it an attractive proposition ... and it's a lot cleaner not just for the environment but also for your garage."

Savic adds that battery bikes are also cheaper  ...

articles.title: Everyone is in a tax reform huddle, except the politicians
articles.text:
Everyone is in a tax reform huddle, except the politicians Domestically, calls for tax reform emanate from the Productivity Commission, the Reserve Bank, and the social services and business sectors.

In fact, from every quarter except the one our political leaders huddle in. Because they have learned the hard way that to raise your head and dare to suggest addressing the inefficient, overly complex, unfair and divisive mess the tax system has become is to expose yourself to the wrath of whichev ...

articles.title: Treasurer seeks to woo female voters by appealing to their hip pockets
articles.text:
Treasurer seeks to woo female voters by appealing to their hip pockets In a bid to secure female votes, Treasurer Josh Frydenberg has talked up the Morrison government's efforts to give Australian women a better financial deal.

Mr Frydenberg's office says that since 2018-19 to the end of 2021, each Australian woman is $3130 better off, on average, as a result of tax cuts.

It says unpublished Australian Taxation Office data showed young women had benefited the most.

"Young Australian women und ...

articles.title: The looming threat of long financial COVID
articles.text:
The looming threat of long financial COVID Policymakers need to recognise the risks to global recovery as vulnerable nations face the spectre of a lost decade. They have been warned.

Economic activity contracted in 90 per cent of the world's countries in 2020. This exceeded the proportion hit by the two world wars, the Great Depression and the global financial crisis.

A pandemic, we now know, is a comprehensive disaster. It also bequeaths ill health and social and economic disruption. Among th ...

articles.title: If you feel like your spending power is going backwards ...
articles.text: If you feel like your spending power is going backwards ... Not even the nation's strongest wages growth is stopping inflation shrinking Tasmanian workers' spending power. Tasmanian wages increased by 3 per cent in 2021, according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics' wage price index, ahead of national growth of 2.3 per cent. However, the state's wages growth significantly trailed the increase in Hobart inflation, which is the best available measure for changes in Tasmanian living costs. The  ...

articles.title: What Australian women need from the next government
articles.text:
What Australian women need from the next government If politicians are looking to attract the female vote, these are the key economic changes that would deliver the greatest benefit to Australian women, according to economists.

Nearly 7700 women return to violent partners every year due to a lack of affordable housing, modelling commissioned by homelessness advocacy group Everybody's Home has found.

Australia needs an additional 16,800 social housing dwellings for women fleeing domestic violen ...

articles.title: 'Not much to celebrate' as gender pay gap narrows slightly
articles.text:
'Not much to celebrate' as gender pay gap narrows slightly On a per-hour comparison, the gap is narrower. According to ABS employee earnings data from August last year, the hourly earnings for men were $37.50 compared with $34.60 for women.

Mary Wooldridge, the Director of the Workplace Gender Equality Agency, said while it was positive that the gender pay gap had dropped, the full effect COVID-19 had on the pay gap was unclear.

"At the point in time of this new national pay gap data, it was a ...

articles.title: Jobs Aussies hate could have pay boost
articles.text:
Jobs Aussies hate could have pay boost Foreign workers are repeatedly ripped off, and critics say new laws to protect them are flawedCourtney GouldNCA NewsWireSat, 26 February 2022 11:47AM

Imagine this: You've travelled to another country to earn some money, but once you arrive you're significantly underpaid, and can only afford to eat plain white rice for every meal to sustain yourself.

That is the reality for many foreign skilled workers in Australia who often suffer in silence over fears th ...

articles.title: Groups want poll fought on more than China
articles.text:
Groups want poll fought on more than China Groups want poll fought on more than ChinaColin BrinsdenAAPMon, 21 February 2022 12:35AM

The coalition and Labor have spent the past week bagging each other over tackling China during a hostile parliamentary sitting.

But business and community groups want the May election to be fought on more than just national security, particularly after two years battling the coronavirus pandemic.

"After an unprecedented two years, the nation faces major challenge ...

articles.title: International students say career opportunities in Australia do not match their qualifications
articles.text:
International students say career opportunities in Australia do not match their qualifications When Moin Rahman graduated from the University of Queensland as a qualified civil engineer, he thought his investment in a reputable international university would mean promising career prospects.

But after applying for more than 80 jobs, the 28-year-old migrant from Bangladesh was unable to find a full-time position in his field.

"That takes a psychological toll," Mr Rahman said.

"After a while, a  ...

articles.title: House-sitting can help out homeless older Aussies  --  but there's a catch
articles.text:
House-sitting can help out homeless older Aussies  --  but there's a catch The severe lack of affordable housing is hurting Australians right across the community -- from young renters, to families seeking to buy and older people needing a stable home.

The number of Australians over 55 who are homeless jumped by 28 per cent between the 2011 and 2016 censuses.

An increasing lack of affordable housing is forcing some older people to take unconventional approaches to finding a home. One of these  ...

articles.title: Economic benefits of improved parental leave and Spotify, where does the money go?
articles.text: Economic benefits of improved parental leave and Spotify, where does the money go? Does extending parental leave entitlements present a greater cost to the Australian economy or a benefit? The answer from economists and gender equality groups seem to agree, it is beneficial for all. Both socially and economically. These benefits extend to unpaid work at home. This does make sense when you listen to economist Jessica Mizrahi, Director at Accenture Australia and Vice President of the Economic Soci ...

articles.title: Probuild collapse could be just the start in a 'broken' system
articles.text:
Probuild collapse could be just the start in a 'broken' system And why has the construction industry's financial plumbing clogged up? Because this is a sector with too much risk and not nearly enough reward.

Clearly Probuild has been caught in something of a perfect storm caused by the pandemic. As Australian Constructors Association chief executive Jon Davies explains, many of its current projects would be being built under fixed-price contracts signed well before the supply chain disruptions  ...

articles.title: Shared equity scheme will solve affordability 'crisis': Grattan
articles.text:
Shared equity scheme will solve affordability 'crisis': Grattan It now takes 12 years for the average Australian to save a 20 per cent deposit for a typical dwelling, up from seven in the early 1990s.

"Even if house prices were to fall by 20 per cent from current levels, it would still take the average Australian about nine years to save a 20 per cent deposit on the average home," writes the Grattan Institute.

Rates of home ownership have fallen across all age groups and income quintiles over  ...

articles.title: The unemployment rate is falling quickly. This 'special formula' explains why
articles.text:
The unemployment rate is falling quickly. This 'special formula' explains why In the last 18 years, it's happened on four separate occasions, and it's seen the unemployment rate decline significantly.

And we're living through one of those periods now.

But this period is radically different from the other three.

Let me explain.

Below is a simplified model of the labour force (LF) framework.

It's used by the Bureau of Statistics to produce our labour force statistics.

It's where numbers like ...

articles.title: Tame, Higgins take aim at PM, demand change
articles.text:
Tame, Higgins take aim at PM, demand change Grace Tame's now infamous 'side eye' to the Prime Minister was provoked by a phone call she had taken a few months earlier during which a senior figure of a government-funded organisation asked the Australian of the Year not to say anything negative about the Prime Minister at the awards event the following January.

The unnamed person told Ms Tame: 'You are an influential person. He will have a fear' and then went on to explain that there was an elect ...

articles.title: Grace Tame and Brittany Higgins speak out as government moves on staffer protections
articles.text:
Grace Tame and Brittany Higgins speak out as government moves on staffer protections The federal government will move to make some initial employment protections for political staffers hours before Grace Tame and Brittany Higgins make a nationally televised address.

Finance Minister Simon Birmingham will introduce legislation on Wednesday morning that addresses some of the recommendations in Sex Discrimination Commissioner Kate Jenkins' review of the parliamentary workplace culture.

Her review ...

articles.title: National Australia Day Council denies 'threatening' Grace Tame call
articles.text:
National Australia Day Council denies 'threatening' Grace Tame call The National Australia Day Council has denied having "threatening" conversations with Grace Tame after the 2021 Australian of the Year said a senior member of a government-funded organisation had urged her to refrain from criticising Prime Minister Scott Morrison.

Mr Morrison hit out at the unnamed person who Ms Tame claimed spoke to her last August, calling on them to apologise for their "unacceptable" behaviour while insistin ...

articles.title: 'We are sorry': Morrison apologises to victims of abuse
articles.text:
'We are sorry': Morrison apologises to victims of abuse "Over many decades, the culture was perpetuated where bullying, abuse, harassment and in some cases even violence became normalised. This has to change, it is changing, and I believe it will change."

Ms Higgins sat in the chamber's gallery, alongside other former Liberal staffers who have alleged mistreatment while working in politics: Rachelle Miller, Chelsey Potter and Josie Coles, as well as consent campaigner Chanel Contos, guests of i ...

articles.title: 'Only words': Brittany's response to PM
articles.text:
'Only words': Brittany's response to PM Grace Tame and Brittany Higgins to address PM's apology at National Press ClubAshleigh GleesonNCA NewsWireWed, 9 February 2022 9:58AM

Brittany Higgins has responded after the Prime Minister personally apologised for her experience working in parliament.

The 27-year-old is giving a highly-anticipated joint address to the National Press Club with former Australian of the Year Grace Tame on Wednesday.

Their speeches come a day after Australia's political l ...

articles.title: One thing missing at bombshell speech
articles.text:
One thing missing at bombshell speech Glaring omission at Grace Tame and Brittany Higgins speechEllen RansleyNCA NewsWireWed, 9 February 2022 4:39PM

The sold-out crowd at Brittany Higgins and Grace Tame National Press Club address on Wednesday might have been primarily women, but both survivors have called for men to help fight the "common enemy".

Ms Higgins, a former Liberal staffer, and Ms Tame, the former Australian of the Year, delivered powerful speeches about their individual experiences ...

articles.title: Push for Grace Tame to name caller
articles.text:
Push for Grace Tame to name caller The federal government says its best chance of thoroughly investigating bombshell claims by former Australian of the Year Grace Tame that she was asked not to criticise the Prime Minister due to the proximity of the election is for her to reveal who was on the other side of the phone.

During her joint National Press Club address with former Liberal staffer and friend Brittany Higgins on Wednesday, Ms Tame described a "threatening" phone call she received in Au ...

articles.title: Higgins, Tame to respond to PM's apology
articles.text:
Higgins, Tame to respond to PM's apology Former Liberal staffer Brittany Higgins and child sexual abuse survivor Grace Tame will respond to Scott Morrison's apology to women harassed and assaulted in federal parliament.

Ms Higgins, who went public a year ago about her alleged 2019 rape in a minister's office, will address the National Press Club with the former Australian of the Year on Wednesday.

Legislation to enact reforms called for by Sex Discrimination Commissioner Kate Jenkins is also d ...

articles.title: 'Threatening' call to Tame sparks inquiry
articles.text:
'Threatening' call to Tame sparks inquiry Both the prime minister's office and organisers of the Australian of the Year Awards have distanced themselves from a "threatening" call to Grace Tame demanding she avoid disparaging Scott Morrison.

The federal government has announced an investigation into the former Australian of the Year's claim and called on the unnamed individual to apologise.

Ms Tame recounted to the National Press Club on Wednesday a "threatening" call from a senior member of a  ...

articles.title: 'We say sorry': Leaders make formal apology to victims of sexual harassment, bullying in Parliament
articles.text:
'We say sorry': Leaders make formal apology to victims of sexual harassment, bullying in Parliament Formal apologies have been made in Parliament to people who experienced sexual harassment, sexual assault or bullying while working for the federal government.

The statements, made in both the House of Representatives and the Senate, were the first recommendation of an independent review conducted last year into the workplace culture within parliamentary offices.

The review was sparked by former ...

articles.title: After Grace Tame's shocking claim, one questions remains: have we learnt nothing?
articles.text:
After Grace Tame's shocking claim, one questions remains: have we learnt nothing? Fierce, formidable and fearless, Grace Tame and Brittany Higgins arrived with one message for the Prime Minister and the nation's most powerful leaders: Act now or face the wrath of their generation.

Time's up.

They have become household names, heroes of their generation, but today they joined together to address a room full of Australia's most powerful political figures with electrifying energy, moral and intell ...

articles.title: Brittany Higgins and Grace Tame to front National Press Club, as parliament proposes legislation aimed at making it a safer workplace
articles.text:
Brittany Higgins and Grace Tame to front National Press Club, as parliament proposes legislation aimed at making it a safer workplace A day after receiving a formal apology from the Prime Minister, former Liberal staffer Brittany Higgins will address the National Press Club alongside her friend and former Australian of the Year, Grace Tame.

The highly anticipated event comes as the federal government prepares to introduce legislation today aimed at implementing some of the recommendations from  ...

articles.title: Sorry always is the hardest word
articles.text: Sorry always is the hardest word Her 12 months as Australian of the Year may be over but Grace Tame continues to speak out. Today as the national capital paused to reflect on the abuse, exploitation and harassment suffered within the halls of power, Ms Tame produced the Twitter equivalent of that side-eye from a couple of weeks ago. The child sexual abuse survivor tweeted "proactive, preventative measures" were needed instead of "performative, last-minute Bandaid electioneering stunts". The parl ...

articles.title: Fordham reacts to Jenny's Tame anger
articles.text:
Fordham reacts to Jenny's Tame anger Ben Fordham has weighed in on comments made by the Prime Minister's wife about Grace Tame's infamous side-eye moment that needed more "manners and respect".

The 2GB journalist and radio presenter spoke on The Today Show on Monday morning, saying he sided with Jenny Morrison.

"I can completely understand where Jenny Morrison's coming from. I mean, I never quite understood what Jenny Morrison had done to upset or offend Grace Tame," he said.

"I completely un ...

articles.title: Liberal calls out sexist attacks from left
articles.text:
Liberal calls out sexist attacks from left Liberal calls out sexist attacks from leftMaeve BannisterAAPWed, 16 February 2022 8:18AM

Liberal MP Nicolle Flint has used her valedictory speech to call out sexism, misogyny and abuse directed at women in the public sphere.

Ms Flint was first elected to federal parliament in 2016 and won again in 2019.

Her time in parliament was marred by "repetitive, sickening, sexist and misogynist behaviour" she says was initiated by the left in the lead up to th ...

articles.title: Veteran told being gay 'a security risk'
articles.text:
Veteran told being gay 'a security risk' Yvonne Sillett was followed, spied on, dragged in front of superiors and effectively forced out of the army for being gay.

And while a lot has changed in the 30 years since her humiliating interrogation, the trailblazing veteran is still yet to receive an apology or evidence that the Australian Defence Force is truly capable of embracing equality.

Ms Sillett was just 18 years old when she began a remarkable decade of service with the Royal Australian Si ...

articles.title: A show of guts and determination
articles.text: A show of guts and determination GRACE Tame and Brittany Higgins have laid the groundwork for the start of many more actions to develop a way to progress forward against child sexual abuse and domestic violence, despite opposition from many sources around them. I salute them both, they have the guts and the determination to propel subjects many people would rather sweep under the carpet and forget about. As a child sexual abuse survivor from the age of six years old from a very close and trusted ...

articles.title: 'Too female': Army captain sacked for something she says men get away with
articles.text:
'Too female': Army captain sacked for something she says men get away with A former army captain has complained to the Australian Human Rights Commission that the Defence Force discriminated against her because she had a relationship with a subordinate, even though she says men have similar relationships without punishment.

Former captain Cassandra Walters, 31, was told last year by the ADF that she would be terminated from the army's 4th Regiment, Royal Australian Artillery, next month for fai ...

articles.title: 'Big shock': League legend's sad reveal
articles.text:
'Big shock': League legend's sad reveal One of the greatest Penrith Panthers' Royce Simmons has revealed he is battling Alzheimer's disease.

The 61-year-old former 238 game veteran, NSW and Australian representative and 20-year coach revealed the tragic news on Thursday.

Stream every game of every round of the 2022 NRL Telstra Premiership Season Live & Ad-Break Free During Play on Kayo. New to Kayo? Try 14-days free now.

Simmons is most remembered from the Panthers' 1991 grand final victory o ...

articles.title: NRL determined to avoid rescheduling games
articles.text:
NRL determined to avoid rescheduling games NRL determined to avoid rescheduling gamesTroy WhittakerAAPThu, 3 February 2022 10:10AM

NRL chief executive Andrew Abdo has outlined the governing body's plan to get through the season without having to reschedule matches due to COVID-19.

He maintains the NRL is aiming the make restrictions in 2022 "as light as possible" so players and officials can enjoy a sense of normality.

While the A-League, AFLW and NBL have recently been forced to postpone fix ...

articles.title: 'It's an everyday thing': Addo-Carr vows to keep calling out racist abuse
articles.text:
'It's an everyday thing': Addo-Carr vows to keep calling out racist abuse The premiership-winning winger said such abuse was a regular occurrence from the moment he began his rugby league career.

"One hundred per cent," Addo-Carr said, when asked if he would continue to shine a spotlight on abuse in a bid to stamp it out.

Addo-Carr took great pride in recreating St Kilda great Nicky Winmar's famous jersey-lifting gesture, which was splashed across the back pages of two Sydney newspapers last w ...

articles.title: Power and passion on show at one of rugby league's best events
articles.text:
Power and passion on show at one of rugby league's best events The NRL season kicked off on Saturday with the Indigenous men's and women's All Stars hosting the Māori All Stars before a large crowd at Parramatta.

Torrential rain wasn't enough to deter a large and passionate crowd for what is one of rugby league's best events of the year. NRL boss Andrew Abdo may be out of practice spending time with large groups of people IRL, but he did a good job of hosting the box along with commissioners Ga ...

articles.title: NRL cashes in on cryptocurrency boom as Bunker gets new sponsor
articles.text:
NRL cashes in on cryptocurrency boom as Bunker gets new sponsor Rugby league has cashed in on the cryptocurrency boom by signing the "largest digital currency exchange sponsorship in Australian sport".

The deal includes naming rights to the NRL's multimillion-dollar Bunker, the in-game video system used to adjudicate on tries and certain refereeing decisions.

The NRL announced on Thursday it had signed a deal for at least three years with Brisbane-based Swyftx, just weeks after the AFL inked a ...

articles.title: Inaccurate Lions pip St Kilda in AFLW
articles.text:
Inaccurate Lions pip St Kilda in AFLW Reigning AFLW premiers Brisbane have overcome a giant scare from winless St Kilda to hang on and win by five points.

The inaccurate Lions trailed the Saints until midway through the third term in oppressive conditions at Trevor Barket Oval in Sandringham on Sunday.

After kicking 11 behinds before slotting their first goal, the Lions rallied after half-time to win 3.13 (31) to 4.2 (26).

The Lions were thrashed by Adelaide in the opening round but have now  ...

articles.title: The Fiona Worts 'feelgood' Maccas story highlights the additional pressures facing ALW players
articles.text:
The Fiona Worts 'feelgood' Maccas story highlights the additional pressures facing ALW players On Sunday afternoon, Adelaide United striker Fiona Worts equalled the A-League Women's all-time record for most goals scored by a single player in a match, netting five in the Reds' 8-2 thumping of Brisbane Roar.

Not only was it her club's biggest win in the history of the competition, but Worts also rocketed up to second on the league's Golden Boot ladder. And with just three rounds left, Adelaide co ...

articles.title: 'I don't have the answer': No timeline on NRLW professionalism says Abdo
articles.text:
'I don't have the answer': No timeline on NRLW professionalism says Abdo NRL chief executive Andrew Abdo says he doesn't know when the NRLW will become a fully professional competition.

At the launch of the rearranged 2021 competition in Newcastle on Tuesday, Abdo could not say when the game's top female players could expect to join the professional ranks.

Despite the NRL this week announcing a $42 million surplus for the 2021 financial year and a trebling in female participation since 2017, A ...

articles.title: Pearcing partnership: The Daisy effect has Harris blooming at the Dees
articles.text:
Pearcing partnership: The Daisy effect has Harris blooming at the Dees Daisy Pearce and Tayla Harris are formidable, high-profile players. Daisy has been the face of AFLW since its inception for her sheer excellence, while Tayla shot to prominence beyond the football world for the iconic photograph of "that kick", and for speaking up against the sexism that followed it.

To me, though, they are the best teammates you could ask for, on and off the field. I have had a front-row seat as Dais has wo ...

articles.title: Souths, Latrell blame Roosters for backlash
articles.text:
Souths, Latrell blame Roosters for backlash Latrell Mitchell said a lot this week, but the line that should be a concern for the game and the NRL is his belief that he is not supported, and almost a loner, in rugby league.

Mitchell made his views known on the state of the game, in particular that the aggression had gone out of rugby league and that we "may as well play Oztag". Those thoughts are valid and controversial at the same time.

They echo what players say privately, but they are headli ...

articles.title: No timeline on NRLW professionalism: Abdo
articles.text:
No timeline on NRLW professionalism: Abdo No timeline on NRLW professionalism: AbdoGeorge ClarkeAAPTue, 22 February 2022 9:40AM

NRL chief executive Andrew Abdo says he doesn't know when the NRLW will become a fully professional competition.

At the launch of the rearranged 2021 competition in Newcastle on Tuesday, Abdo could not say when the game's top female players could expect to join the professional ranks.

Despite the NRL this week announcing a $42million surplus for the 2021 financial ye ...

articles.title: Sheed slams 'DISGUSTING' abuse directed at Ryan's kids
articles.text:
Sheed slams 'DISGUSTING' abuse directed at Ryan's kids West Coast midfielder Dom Sheed has revealed star forward Liam Ryan had taken Monday off to spend time with his family in the wake of racist abuse directed at his twin boys over the weekend.

Ryan was noticeably absent from training yesterday after the Eagles participated in an intra-club hit out on Saturday night, with Sheed revealing the "disgusting" abuse was behind the 25-year-old's absence.

Sheed said the club was steadfast in their su ...

articles.title: Demons beat Kangaroos for fourth straight win after Crows, Cats triumph
articles.text:
Demons beat Kangaroos for fourth straight win after Crows, Cats triumph Melbourne has put itself in prime position to land a prized AFLW top-two spot after fighting out a 10-point win over the Kangaroos at Casey Fields.

In Saturday's other matches, the Adelaide Crows stayed on top of the ladder with a nine-point victory over Fremantle, and Geelong defeated Richmond by 23 points.

The Demons led almost all night and their disciplined defence withstood a barrage of pressure from the in-form Kanga ...

articles.title: Football Australia launches Indigenous reconciliation action plan
articles.text:
Football Australia launches Indigenous reconciliation action plan Football Australia (FA) has become the latest national sports governing body to develop and implement a reconciliation action plan (RAP), a program endorsed by Reconciliation Australia that aims to build and strengthen football's relationship with First Nations communities.

It is the first time football's national body has launched its own RAP, with it following in the footsteps of other organisations such as the AFL, NRL, and Cr ...

articles.title: Eagles back Ryan after more online racism
articles.text:
Eagles back Ryan after more online racism Livewire West Coast forward Liam Ryan has briefly had time off from the club after the AFL's latest online racism incident.

Teammate Dom Sheed has joined the Eagles in slamming the social media post, which referenced Ryan's young children.

"It's disgusting, there's no other way of saying it," Sheed said on Tuesday.

"It's unacceptable and it's disgusting to see.

"Liam had the day off yesterday to be with his family and this stuff continues to happen.  ...
